channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: American Ship Loading Syrian Chemicals for Destruction at Sea
item.description: The cargo is part of a 1,300-ton stockpile of toxins removed from Syria under an international deal brokered last year and brought to Italy.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The Cape Ray on Wednesday began loading toxic chemicals from Syria at a port in Italy for destruction at sea.

item.title: Iraqi Premier Says Says Fight Against ISIS Is Top Priority
item.description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said defeating extremist Sunni groups was more important than bridging Iraq’s political divide to form a unity government.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq, center, with lawmakers on Tuesday.

item.title: Possible Revenge Killing Adds to Tension in Israel
item.description: Reports that an Arab teenager was forced into a car and the discovery of a body raised fears of retaliation for the deaths of three Israeli youths.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A Palestinian threw a stone at the Israeli police during clashes on Wednesday in Shuafat, a neighborhood in Jerusalem.

item.title: Sarkozy Placed Under Formal Investigation in Corruption Case
item.description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former French president, was detained for 15 hours as the authorities examined whether he sought to illegally obtain information from a judge.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Uphill Fight Ahead for Hong Kong’s Democracy Movement
item.description: Hong Kong’s huge pro-democracy march Tuesday underscored the determination of many of its residents to preserve their freedoms but also brought some challenges to light.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Bangladesh’s Rotten-Mango Crisis
item.description: A dispute over contaminated mangoes reveals a growing chasm between the city and the country.
item.dc:creator: By TAHMIMA ANAM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Sees Long Road to Cleaning Up Pollution
item.description: A state-run newspaper says it will take at least 16 years for China to attain safe levels of dangerous particulate matter in its air, but even that is in doubt.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A man wearing a mask on a smoggy day in Beijing in March.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Caliphate Fantasy
item.description: ISIS claims to have restored an Islamic state, but the reality of the caliphs was far different from what the jihadists imagine.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KHALED DIAB

item.title: Pistorius at Increasing Risk of Suicide, Lawyer Says
item.description: A psychologist’s report read at the South African athlete’s murder trial said he needs to be treated for post-traumatic stress and depression.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Cybercrime Scheme Aims at Payments in Brazil
item.description: Researchers say transactions worth $3.75 billion were compromised, though it is not clear how much was stolen.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Hong Kong, a Potent Visual Echo of Tiananmen
item.description: Amid the protesters in the city on Tuesday was a papier-mâché replica of the Goddess of Democracy statue, the icon of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, this one built by students born years after Beijing’s bloody crackdown.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Marchers carried a scaled-down replica of the Goddess of Democracy, an icon of the 1989 protests in Tiananmen Square in Beijing, during Hong Kong's pro-democracy demonstration Tuesday.

item.title: Lens Blog: War’s Lingering Requiem in Vietnam
item.description: A museum in Vietnam memorialized the work of photographers who died covering the conflict. It includes indelible images by Western photojournalists as well as North Vietnamese photographers.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By DONATELLA LORCH
item.media:description: Toward the end of the Cambodian war, almost the entire population of the country was homeless. Cambodia. 1975.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Time-Lapse Video Shows Steady Stream of Hong Kong Protesters
item.description: Just how many people participated in Hong Kong’s pro-democracy march on Tuesday? A video gives a sense of the demonstration’s scale.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills 8 in Afghan Capital
item.description: A suicide bomber attacked an air force bus in Afghanistan's capital early Wednesday, killing eight military personnel and wounding another 13, security officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: BlaBlaCar, a Ride-Sharing Start-Up in Europe, Looks to Expand Its Map
item.description: More than eight million people use BlaBlaCar, a hitch-a-ride online service which says it has raised $100 million from American and European venture firms.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: BlaBlaCar takes 12 percent for rides it arranges. The drivers share the costs, but cannot profit.

item.title: Rev. Christian Führer, East German Whose Prayers Inspired Protests, Dies at 71
item.description: Pastor Führer’s “prayers for peace” meetings in Leipzig grew into mass demonstrations that helped bring about the fall of Communism in East Germany.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: After Retreat, Iraqi Soldiers Fault Officers
item.description: When Iraq’s security forces crumbled in the face of militants, they were labeled cowards. But in the case of one brigade, at least, what emerges instead is a portrait of mismanagement and treachery.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: The remnants of the Ninth Brigade of Iraq’s border guards at Al-Ukhaidir fortress, far from the positions they once held.

item.title: World Briefing: France: European Rights Court Upholds French Ban on Veils
item.description: The European Court of Human Rights has upheld a French ban on wearing face-covering veils in public, rejecting arguments that the measure violates religious freedoms.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: Suspects in Killing of DEA Agent Handed to U.S.
item.description: Seven Colombians accused of involvement in the stabbing death of a United States drug agent were handed over to American authorities on Tuesday at a police base in Bogotá.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Protesters in Hong Kong Confront Beijing Over Elections
item.description: The demonstration Tuesday rivaled the territory’s largest-ever pro-democracy march in size, as thousands filled the streets to call for more democratic methods to choose the next chief executive.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Envoy to Afghanistan and Pakistan Will Leave Post
item.description: James F. Dobbins said the present election impasse in Afghanistan threatens more division in the country.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: James Dobbins appearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee during its hearing on the progress of withdrawal of American troops from Afghanistan in December 2013.

item.title: Benghazi Suspect Said to Corroborate Important Details of Attacks
item.description: American officials said Ahmed Abu Khattala has not incriminated himself in the killing of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three others, but he has provided interrogators with “key facts” about what occurred on the day of the attacks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Belgium 2, United States 1: World Cup 2014: Belgium Eliminates Team U.S.A.
item.description: The United States was eliminated from the World Cup by Belgium despite a memorable performance from goalkeeper Tim Howard.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Belgium's Kevin De Bruyne scored the first goal of the match.

item.title: Putin Warns Again of Force as Ukraine Fighting Spreads
item.description: Fighting resumed in the east early Tuesday, including artillery shelling around the rebel-controlled city of Slovyansk, after President Petro O. Poroshenko ended a 10-day cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A resident surveyed damage from recent shelling in Slovyansk, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Deeply Divided Israel Unites in Grief and Sees a Larger Purpose
item.description: A day after the bodies of three kidnapped Israeli teenagers were found in the West Bank, thousands gathered to bury them side by side, wrapped in Israeli flags.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
